NO, THIS ISN'T A JOKE
Four classes hold their elections this week. Probably eight sets
of caucuses will be held—or possibly have been held—this week.
Of course, we realize that it is necessary to have some system in
selecting the man for whom you are going to vote. When two or
three or four equally good men are up for an office, it is so hard
to decide who is really the best man. Therefore, why not let's
get together with the Mu Pis and see if we can't get Bill elected
secretary? After all, he's 'as good as anybody else, and he is our
fraternity brother.
This line of reasoning is almost irrefutable, now isn't it? If
Bill is just as good as anybody else, and you like Bill a little better
than the rest, why not try to get Bill into office? But unfortunately, in many cases, Bill isn't as good as the other fellow, though
his followers may not realize it. The second step of the argument
holds good anyway, and a big combine is formed to insure Bill's
election.
Bill is elected. The other crowd cries "Politics!" just as loudly
as Bill's crowd would have yelled if Bill had been defeated. The
Mu Pis slander the Zi Delts for eight months, but Bill is secretary.
Any exhortation to eliminate politics from student elections
usually calls forth either snickers or cynicism or utter disregard
of the exhorter. Is it absolutely impossible for a man to be
elected_ to office purely on his own qualifications? Or must the
bartering ability of his friends decide the issue? It usually does.

AN IRRADIATION OF -HIGHER EDUCATION"
An advertisement in the May 28 issue of the Harvard Crimson
appealed so strongly to our sense,of humor that we have been
tempted to quote part of it in this column. An enterprising group
of people, trading under the name "The College Tutoring Bureau"
has gathered together "complete, accurate, reliable, well-typed
reviews and notes" of most of the popular courses in the university and offers them for sale to those who need preparation for
the final examinations.
The list includes numerous courses in all departments. For
example, one can secure this most invaluable crutch for English
28, 2, 11b, 33, 29b, 35b, 50b, 73, 41 and 48. Other subjects are not
covered quite as exhaustively, but the assortment is ample. Some
courses come under the general heading of the advertisement, but
others are favored with a more detailed blurb. Students taking
"Psychology A,"for example, could secure "a complete outline
of text-book and all lectures." And as an added. inducement:
"a short, snappy outline of the Essential Rules of German Grammar given away without charge" to German A students.
No wonder Brother Mencken rants against the colleges! Maybe
the only reason why nobody has tried out this admirable method
of'making money here at Hopkins is that the undergraduate body
is too small to make the venture worth while. Nevertheless, such
• organizations as "The College Tutoring Bureau" strike us as being
very forceful arguments for the New Plan.

following themes:

Nights.
(2) The Literature of Abyssinia.
(3) Modern Arabic Folk-Literature.

dialect).

DR. WIGHT SPEAKS

Rodgers and Aiau Furnish Entertainment
LARGE CROWD PRESENT
Freshman Orchestra Provides
Evening's Music
About three hundred and twentyfive men attended the Y. M. C. A.
reception for freshmen last Friday
night. The affair, which was held
in the Civil Engineering Hall,
turned out to be the usual rushing
party. This year there were many
more upper classmen than freshmen, the ratio being about two to
one.
The music for the affair was furnished by a freshman orchestra
under the leadership of Osmar
Steinwald.
Dr. Wight on Activities.

Dr. Carol V. B. Wight, who succeeded Dr. John F. French as chairman of the faculty committee on
student affairs when the latter became Librarian of the University,
was the speaker of the evening. Dr.
Wight spoke at length on the relation of extra curricular activities to
college life. It was pointed out by
him that the proper ratio between
studies and activities must be maintained in order that the student
might get the most out of his college
experience.
Athletics Good Training

Dr. Wight said that he thought
athletics good training for college
men, in that sports put a man on his
own, teaches generosity and aids a
man to learn to keep his temper
under control. Fraternities, Dr.
Wight believed, are also very helpful and beneficial and may prove of
(Treat value in later life. The welcome the freshman class got, Dr.
Wight said, would last throughout
the time they were at college and
should be passed on to the incoming
classes of future years.
Bill Rodgers was next on the program and his entertainment was as
lively and as appreciated as usual.
Rodgers sang some humorous songs
as well as several of the old favorites and ended up his part of the
program by offering "The Curse of
Drink."
Native Hawaiian Performs

The second bit of entertainment
was furnished by C. K. Aiau, a native Hawaiian, who has been studying at the Johns Hopkins Medical
School. Aiau performed on the
guitar, the ukelele and another
stringed instrument.
Refreshments, in the form of ice
cream and cake, were served after
the last musical number.

Stressed By Captain

Organization of the track squad
for the coming season was begun
t a meeting held in the M. E. Building on last Friday. The gathering
was addressed by Capt. Herman
Schiebel of the Cross Country
Team, Capt. A. E. Vivell of the

Edwards, pilot of the Black and

"The Work is not hard, and anyone

running can develop into a fairly
good hill and dale man through
steady practice." All men running
distances upwards from half-mile
were requested to try out for the
team.

Lighter Uniform
Coach Ray Van Orman has made
a change in the uniforms being worn
by the football team this year. The
new uniform weighs approximately
eight and one-half pounds. This is
just six and one-half pounds lighter
than last year's togs, which weighed
fifteen.
The idea of a light •uniform was
conceived by the United States Military Academy and was first put into
practice in the Army-Navy game of
1926. These uniforms were such
an improvement over the heavier
ones that the A. G. Spalding Co.,
manufacturers of the new uniforms,
placed them on display in New
York. It was here that Coach Van
Orman received the idea which he
has put into practice.
New uniforms were bought at
the Hopkins athletic outfitters, and
were first put into use against Richmond. One feature of the new uniform is the detachable hip pads.
These protectors are strapped and
the jersey pulled down over them.

from the pants. This gives the opposing team less opportunity to hold
on to a man after he has been tackled. The head gears are lined with
sponge rubber instead of felt, making them lighter, more impervious

NO, THIS ISN'T A JOKE
Four classes hold their elections this week. Probably eight sets
of caucuses will be held—or possibly have been held—this week.
Of course, we realize that it is necessary to have some system in
selecting the man for whom you are going to vote. When two or
three or four equally good men are up for an office, it is so hard
to decide who is really the best man. Therefore, why not let's
get together with the Mu Pis and see if we can't get Bill elected
secretary? After all, he's 'as good as anybody else, and he is our
fraternity brother.
This line of reasoning is almost irrefutable, now isn't it? If
Bill is just as good as anybody else, and you like Bill a little better
than the rest, why not try to get Bill into office? But unfortunately, in many cases, Bill isn't as good as the other fellow, though
his followers may not realize it. The second step of the argument
holds good anyway, and a big combine is formed to insure Bill's
election.
Bill is elected. The other crowd cries "Politics!" just as loudly
as Bill's crowd would have yelled if Bill had been defeated. The
Mu Pis slander the Zi Delts for eight months, but Bill is secretary.
Any exhortation to eliminate politics from student elections
usually calls forth either snickers or cynicism or utter disregard
of the exhorter. Is it absolutely impossible for a man to be
elected_ to office purely on his own qualifications? Or must the
bartering ability of his friends decide the issue? It usually does.

An advertisement in the May 28 issue of the Harvard Crimson
appealed so strongly to our sense,of humor that we have been
tempted to quote part of it in this column. An enterprising group
of people, trading under the name "The College Tutoring Bureau"
has gathered together "complete, accurate, reliable, well-typed
reviews and notes" of most of the popular courses in the university and offers them for sale to those who need preparation for
the final examinations.
The list includes numerous courses in all departments. For
example, one can secure this most invaluable crutch for English
28, 2, 11b, 33, 29b, 35b, 50b, 73, 41 and 48. Other subjects are not
covered quite as exhaustively, but the assortment is ample. Some
courses come under the general heading of the advertisement, but
others are favored with a more detailed blurb. Students taking
"Psychology A,"for example, could secure "a complete outline
of text-book and all lectures." And as an added. inducement:
"a short, snappy outline of the Essential Rules of German Grammar given away without charge" to German A students.
No wonder Brother Mencken rants against the colleges! Maybe
the only reason why nobody has tried out this admirable method
of'making money here at Hopkins is that the undergraduate body
is too small to make the venture worth while. Nevertheless, such
• organizations as "The College Tutoring Bureau" strike us as being
very forceful arguments for the New Plan.

DR. WIGHT SPEAKS

Rodgers and Aiau Furnish Entertainment
LARGE CROWD PRESENT
Freshman Orchestra Provides
Evening's Music
About three hundred and twentyfive men attended the Y. M. C. A.
reception for freshmen last Friday
night. The affair, which was held
in the Civil Engineering Hall,
turned out to be the usual rushing
party. This year there were many
more upper classmen than freshmen, the ratio being about two to
one.
The music for the affair was furnished by a freshman orchestra
under the leadership of Osmar
Steinwald.
Dr. Wight on Activities.

Dr. Carol V. B. Wight, who succeeded Dr. John F. French as chairman of the faculty committee on
student affairs when the latter became Librarian of the University,
was the speaker of the evening. Dr.
Wight spoke at length on the relation of extra curricular activities to
college life. It was pointed out by
him that the proper ratio between
studies and activities must be maintained in order that the student
might get the most out of his college
experience.
Athletics Good Training

Dr. Wight said that he thought
athletics good training for college
men, in that sports put a man on his
own, teaches generosity and aids a
man to learn to keep his temper
under control. Fraternities, Dr.
Wight believed, are also very helpful and beneficial and may prove of
(Treat value in later life. The welcome the freshman class got, Dr.
Wight said, would last throughout
the time they were at college and
should be passed on to the incoming
classes of future years.
Bill Rodgers was next on the program and his entertainment was as
lively and as appreciated as usual.
Rodgers sang some humorous songs
as well as several of the old favorites and ended up his part of the
program by offering "The Curse of
Drink."
Native Hawaiian Performs

The second bit of entertainment
was furnished by C. K. Aiau, a native Hawaiian, who has been studying at the Johns Hopkins Medical
School. Aiau performed on the
guitar, the ukelele and another
stringed instrument.
Refreshments, in the form of ice
cream and cake, were served after
the last musical number.
